external_references.description: CISA; FBI; HHS. (2020, November 2). Ransomware Activity Targeting the Healthcare and Public Health Sector. Retrieved September 9, 2025.

objects.name: Malicious Healthcare File
objects.description:
Adversaries may rely upon a user opening a malicious healthcare file in order to gain execution. Users (e.g., clinicians, technologists, support staff, etc.) may be socially engineered to open or import a file that leads to code execution. This action maybe observed as follow-on behavior from [Spearphishing Attachment](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001), or delivery via shared repositories and clinical workflows.

Healthcare environments frequently treat clinical files as “known-good”, and carve out exceptions in AV/EDR and content gateways to preserve care delivery (e.g., scan exclusions on PACS drop folders and viewer processes). This implicit trust reduces telemetry and creates blind spots that adversaries can exploit, making sector-specific files an appealing execution vehicle.

Adversaries may use several types of healthcare-specific files that require a user or workflow to open/ingest them, including: DICOM images (.dcm) and study bundles (e.g., DICOMDIR/archives), viewer project/session files, clinical document formats (e.g., C-CDA/FHIR XML/JSON), ECG/waveform formats, HL7 messages (.hl7, often plain-text pipe-delimited), and vendor-proprietary clinical files. Opening or importing these artifacts can exploit file-format quirks (e.g., preambles) or parser vulnerabilities in viewers, PACS clients, or clinical tooling - resulting in memory corruption or code execution. Attackers may employ [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) and [Obfuscated Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027) (e.g., familiar patient/study naming or password-protected archives with “how-to-open” instructions) to increase the likelihood of successful execution.

While Malicious Healthcare File may occur shortly after Initial Access, it may also occur at other phases of an intrusion. For example, when an adversary places a crafted study in a shared directory, imaging workstation inbox, or PACS/RIS “watch folder” - hoping that a user or automated import pipeline will open or ingest it.

Recent federal guidance documents hospital-targeted ransomware campaigns that rely on user-initiated execution, underscoring this sub-technique’s relevance to HPH environments (Citation: CISA-FBI-HHS AA20-302A).
objects.x_mitre_detection:
Monitor the execution and command-line arguments of clinical applications that require user interaction or automated ingest (e.g., imaging viewers and PACS/RIS/interface-engine utilities). Treat the opening/importing of sector-specific file types as a detection pivot and correlate follow-on activity from the same process/user.

Endpoint and network sensors can detect malicious events once a clinical file is opened - for example, a viewer or ingest service making unexpected outbound connections or spawning a scripting shell/LOLBIN (e.g., cmd.exe, powershell.exe, wscript, mshta, rundll32) shortly after a study is opened. Where EDR exclusions exist for clinical apps or “watch folders,” rely on application/queue telemetry and file-structure inspection.

Heuristics useful in healthcare environments include:

• File/Metadata Checks: verify format structure; for DICOM, confirm “DICM” at offset 128 and flag executable headers (PE/ELF) in the preamble, malformed element lengths, suspicious/mismatched transfer syntaxes, or unusual/private tags.

• Application/Queue Health: viewer/PACS crashes or parser exceptions; ingest retries/aborts; sudden growth of interface-engine/PACS queues; increased latency between modality ingest and worklist availability.

• Process Lineage: clinical apps writing new executables/DLLs or spawning child processes shortly after file open/import; unusual module loads from temp/user-profile paths.

• Network Timing/Context: DNS or egress from viewer/PACS hosts immediately following a study open/import; connections to destinations not typical for imaging workflows.

Correlate detections with the specific file hash/StudyInstanceUID, the user/system that opened/imported it, and the source path (email attachment, shared drive, removable media, or PACS/interface-engine drop location) to support rapid triage and hunting.
x_mitre_system_requirements: Endpoint with a clinical viewer or ingest service that opens sector-specific files (e.g., DICOM); a vulnerable/misconfigured parser or pre-patch build; a permitted delivery path that causes a user or local workflow to open/import the file; no upstream normalization removing unsafe structures; execution occurs in user context (no admin required).

external_references.description: Sector overlap: UNC3890 includes healthcare orgs among targets. Added for HPH context; no shared operator implied.

objects.name: Operation Code Blue
objects.description: A ransomware campaign impacting U.S. hospitals wherein WIZARD SPIDER/UNC1878 operators used Ryuk (often following TrickBot/Bazar) to encrypt clinical systems and disrupt care delivery. The window for this exemplar spans Oct 2019 (DCH Health System) through Oct 2020 (Sky Lakes Medical Center/St. Lawrence Health System), coinciding with federal warnings of heightened Ryuk activity against HPH.

objects.name: Sector-Specific File Normalization
objects.description:
Normalize clinical files at an ingest boundary so only a policy-conformant, re-serialized version reaches viewers/PACS and interface engines. Strip ambiguous/unsafe structures and re-encode to an allow-listed subset to neutralize parser abuse and polyglots.

Implementation Highlights (DICOM):

• Enforce "DICM" at offset 128; zero/reject non-essential preamble; block PE/ELF magic in the preamble.

• Transcode to an allow-listed transfer syntax; validate element lengths and SOP Class/UIDs; remove/allow-list private tags; re-serialize with a trusted library.

• Fail-closed: quarantine on any validation error and log (file hash, StudyInstanceUID, source path, timestamp).

Operational Notes:

• Place normalization in front of PACS watch folders/interface engines; pair with endpoint rules that block viewer child-process creation for defense-in-depth.

• Normalize at ingest—not on endpoints—so vulnerable parsers never touch the original file.

• For HL7/FHIR/C-CDA: Enforce strict schema/length/encoding checks and strip embedded/active content before downstream processing.

objects.name: Analytic 1201
objects.description: Detects booby-trapped clinical images by validating DICOM structure as recorded in viewer/PACS logs. Alert when the file is missing “DICM” at byte offset 128, the 128-byte preamble contains executable magic (e.g., MZ or ELF), transfer syntax is unsupported/mismatched for the SOP Class, element lengths are out of bounds, or private tags fall outside an allow-list. On match: log file path/hash, StudyInstanceUID, user/host, and timestamp; quarantine if available.

x_mitre_mutable_elements.description: JSON array of Transfer Syntax UIDs considered normal here. Any other UID (or a SOP-Class/UID mismatch) raises severity.

objects.name: Healthcare Imaging Workstation
objects.description: Workstation used by radiologists/technologists to view studies. Receives DICOM via PACS watch folders, shared drives, removable media, or email. .dcm files are associated to a desktop viewer (e.g., MicroDicom). Clinical apps may be exempted from some EDR rules to preserve workflow. Risk: a crafted DICOM can trigger a viewer/parser bug on open, leading to user-context code execution and post-open child processes/network activity.

x_mitre_related_assets.name: Radiology Ingest Server
x_mitre_related_assets.description: Server/service that receives and routes, for example, DICOM studies to PACS and viewer workstations via C-STORE/C-MOVE (and often watch-folder file drops). It may transcode transfer syntaxes, handle private tags, and write studies to archive/worklists - frequently with AV/EDR exceptions for throughput. A booby-trapped .dcm can be passed downstream to the Imaging Workstation or trigger server-side parsing faults here. This node is the best choke point to enforce Sector-Specific File Normalization and to collect ingest telemetry (association logs, rejects/retries, queue/latency metrics, transcode outcomes).

objects.name: Clinical File Telemetry
objects.description: Application-level telemetry from imaging viewers and PACS services that records file open/import events and parsing outcomes for clinical study files. Typical fields include file path/hash, StudyInstanceUID, SOP Class UID, Transfer Syntax UID, preamble status (e.g., “DICM” @128, non-zero preamble), parser exceptions, and ingest/queue results (reject/retry/latency). Useful to detect Malicious Healthcare File behavior such as preamble/polyglot tricks, malformed element lengths, spoofed transfer syntaxes, and unusual/private tag usage.

objects.name: Open/Import Event
objects.description: An event from viewer/PACS software that records opening or importing a clinical file (e.g., DICOM) and the parser’s outcome. Typical fields include file path/hash, user/host, StudyInstanceUID, SOP Class UID, Transfer Syntax UID, preamble status (DICM @128, preamble bytes, exec-magic present), private tag owners, element-length validation results, parser exceptions, and ingest disposition (accepted/rejected/quarantined). Supports detection of Malicious Healthcare File (QNTK-T1204.121) patterns (preamble/polyglot, spoofed transfer syntax, malformed elements) and correlation with post-open process/network activity.

external_references.description: Brian Krebs. (2023, May 30). Discord Admins Hacked by Malicious Bookmarks. Retrieved January 2, 2024.

Tiago Pereira. (2023, November 2). Attackers use JavaScript URLs, API forms and more to scam users in popular online game “Roblox”. Retrieved January 2, 2024.
Tommy Madjar, Dusty Miller, Selena Larson. (2024, June 17). From Clipboard to Compromise: A PowerShell Self-Pwn. Retrieved August 2, 2024.

objects.name: User Execution
objects.description:
An adversary may rely upon specific actions by a user in order to gain execution. Users may be subjected to social engineering to get them to execute malicious code by, for example, opening a malicious document file or link. These user actions will typically be observed as follow-on behavior from forms of [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566).

While [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204) frequently occurs shortly after Initial Access it may occur at other phases of an intrusion, such as when an adversary places a file in a shared directory or on a user's desktop hoping that a user will click on it. This activity may also be seen shortly after [Internal Spearphishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1534).

Adversaries may also deceive users into performing actions such as:

* Enabling [Remote Access Tools](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1219), allowing direct control of the system to the adversary
* Running malicious JavaScript in their browser, allowing adversaries to [Steal Web Session Cookie](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1539)s(Citation: Talos Roblox Scam 2023)(Citation: Krebs Discord Bookmarks 2023)
* Downloading and executing malware for [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)
* Coerceing users to copy, paste, and execute malicious code manually(Citation: Reliaquest-execution)(Citation: proofpoint-selfpwn)

For example, tech support scams can be facilitated through [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566), vishing, or various forms of user interaction. Adversaries can use a combination of these methods, such as spoofing and promoting toll-free numbers or call centers that are used to direct victims to malicious websites, to deliver and execute payloads containing malware or [Remote Access Tools](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1219).(Citation: Telephone Attack Delivery)
objects.x_mitre_detection:
Monitor the execution of and command-line arguments for applications that may be used by an adversary to gain Initial Access that require user interaction. This includes compression applications, such as those for zip files, that can be used to [Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1140) in payloads.

Anti-virus can potentially detect malicious documents and files that are downloaded and executed on the user's computer. Endpoint sensing or network sensing can potentially detect malicious events once the file is opened (such as a Microsoft Word document or PDF reaching out to the internet or spawning powershell.exe).

objects.name: Wizard Spider
objects.description: [Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) is a Russia-based financially motivated threat group originally known for the creation and deployment of [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) since at least 2016. [Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) possesses a diverse arsenal of tools and has conducted ransomware campaigns against a variety of organizations, ranging from major corporations to hospitals.(Citation: CrowdStrike Ryuk January 2019)(Citation: DHS/CISA Ransomware Targeting Healthcare October 2020)(Citation: CrowdStrike Wizard Spider October 2020)

objects.name: Ryuk
objects.description: [Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) is a ransomware designed to target enterprise environments that has been used in attacks since at least 2018. [Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) shares code similarities with Hermes ransomware.(Citation: CrowdStrike Ryuk January 2019)(Citation: FireEye Ryuk and Trickbot January 2019)(Citation: FireEye FIN6 Apr 2019)

“Operation Code Blue” aligns with 2019-2020 hospital-focused ransomware activity conducted by WIZARD SPIDER/UNC1878, which leveraged TrickBot/Bazar access to deploy Ryuk (and later Conti) against HPH organizations. Public and government reporting during Oct 2020 explicitly warned hospitals of Ryuk activity tied to this actor set.

Public reporting on the 2019–2020 hospital ransomware wave (Ryuk/UNC1878/WIZARD SPIDER) emphasizes phishing and user-initiated execution in HPH environments. While no report explicitly documents healthcare-specific file types being weaponized in those incidents, the target set (hospitals) and the sector’s reliance on trusted clinical files make a file-based execution vector credible. In parallel, DICOM and other clinical formats have documented design/implementation issues (e.g., CVE-2019-11687 DICOM preamble polyglot) that demonstrate feasibility. Accordingly, this relationship is marked hypothesized (low confidence) to inform detections and mitigations without over-claiming attribution.

During Operation Code Blue, the actor set commonly associated with WIZARD SPIDER/UNC1878 deployed Ryuk ransomware against U.S. hospitals - often after initial access via TrickBot/BazarLoader. Notable incidents include DCH Health System (Oct 2019) and the Oct 27, 2020 attacks on Sky Lakes Medical Center (OR) and St. Lawrence Health System (NY). A joint CISA/FBI/HHS advisory warned the HPH sector of imminent Ryuk/Conti activity during this period.

Sector-Specific File Normalization mitigates QNTK-T1204.121 (Malicious Healthcare File) by re-serializing clinical files at a trusted boundary so vulnerable viewers and ingest services never touch the original artifact. 

For DICOM - policy enforces DICM at offset 128, zeros or rejects the preamble, blocks PE/ELF magic, transcodes to an allow-listed transfer syntax, validates element lengths/SOP Class/UIDs, and removes/allow-lists private tags. This neutralizes preamble/polyglot and parser-abuse vectors, reducing downstream child-process spawns and crashes. 

Quarantine + logging (file hash, StudyInstanceUID, source path, timestamp) activities provide telemetry to correlate detections.

During hospital-focused operations associated with Ryuk, operators relied on user-initiated execution following delivered content. Although open sources do not document healthcare-specific files in those incidents, it is plausible that a booby-trapped clinical file (e.g., DICOM) could be delivered to radiology staff and opened, triggering a viewer/parser bug and launching a loader under the user context - consistent with Malicious Healthcare File (QNTK-T1204.121).

Operators deliver a booby-trapped clinical file (e.g., DICOM) that a clinician opens in a Windows viewer. The crafted content triggers a parsing bug, executing a lightweight stager that fetches/drops Ryuk, which then encrypts local/accessible systems. This aligns with Ryuk’s reliance on user-initiated execution while adapting it to healthcare’s trusted file paths.

Detect execution attempts triggered by sector-specific files by validating, for example, DICOM structure recorded in viewer/PACS logs. This strategy uses Analytic QNTK-AN1201 to flag missing “DICM” @128, executable headers in the preamble (MZ/ELF), transfer-syntax/SOP Class mismatches, out-of-bounds element lengths, and unapproved private tags. On match, alert and capture file path/hash, StudyInstanceUID, user/host, and timestamp; quarantine when available.

This asset represents the endpoint where the sub-technique is realized: a radiology viewer host that opens/ingests clinical files from PACS watch folders, shares, or email. A booby-trapped DICOM (or similar sector file) can trigger a viewer/parser flaw on open, leading to user-context execution and potential child-process/network activity. Typical risk factors include .dcm file association to the viewer and reduced EDR coverage for clinical apps.

This component records clinical file open/import and parser outcomes from viewer/PACS software. It enables detection of booby-trapped files consistent with QNTK-T1204.121: missing “DICM” at byte 128, executable magic in the preamble, spoofed/mismatched transfer syntax, out-of-bounds element lengths, unapproved private tags, and parse errors—plus correlation to post-open behavior.
